title: Nunney Walks

images.caption: The Market Place and Castle

images.caption: Moat, at the castle. The castle is a small, French style castle surrounded by a deep moat, built for Sir John Delamare in 1373.

images.title: Graham Horn / Fallen trees in Nunney Combe
images.caption: Fallen trees in Nunney Combe. A lovely path follows Nunney Brook through woodland. The stream has many fallen trees. It also has very little water, already (May) this year.

images.title: Trish Steel, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Gatehouse, Whatley. This building dates from c1500 and is built of limestone rubble. The mouldings are of Tudor design. The building is Grade I listed

images.title: Patrick Mackie / Macmillan Way
images.caption: Macmillan Way. The Macmillan Way descends from Whatley into the combe below just beyond the next hedge.

images.title: Patrick Mackie / Barn and archway
images.caption: Barn and archway. Just beyond the northern wall of the parish church at Whatley.

description: This picturesque Somerset village is a lovely place for a stroll. There's a medieval moated castle, a 12th century church, lots of quaint old cottages and a pretty brook running through the centre of the village. This walk from the village visits Nunney Castle , Nunney Coombe and the neighbouring village of Whatley. The walk starts in the village centre where you can pick up the Macmillan Way and follow the waymarked trail north along the Nunney Brook to Nunney Coombe. There's some nice woodland trails around here as you continue north to Whatley. Here there's a Vineyard and trails along Fordbury Water to the north of the village. The route then retraces its steps south before following an alternative public footpath to visit the remains of Nunney Castle. The moated 14th century castle was modernised in the late 16th century, and then besieged and damaged by the Parliamentarians in 1645, during the English Civil War. The site is now run by English Heritage and is free to access with a free car park, a short walk away, off Castle Hill. It's also notable as England's smallest medieval castle.
